results.title: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows
results.creator_credit: Pat Fiske, Megan McMurchy, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bower Bird Films
results.brief_description: Fred Hollows was a controversial, larger-than-life character who was abrasive, determined, flamboyant, unconventional and full of contradictions. Some loved him, some hated him. The style of this film, like the man, is direct, forthright, warts and all. Rather than conquer and convert, his philosophy was to train indigenous people to help themselves and this film documents his work in Eritrea, Nepal and here in Australia with the Aborigines. Included is film shot during recent expeditions, archival material and interviews and glimpses of him at home and on the road. “For all the world to see” is bold, wry, intimate and ultimately a very moving tribute to an extraordinary life.

results.title: Who killed Malcolm Smith?
results.creator_credit: Caroline Sherwood, Nicholas Adler, Film Australia and Titus Films
results.brief_description: On December 29, 1982 Malcolm Smith killed himself in prison. Richard Frankland, a commissioner for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody revisits friends and family to find out circumstances of his death and First Peoples in custody generally.

constellations_other.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_other.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Caroline Sherwood, Nicholas Adler, Film Australia and Titus Films
results.description: On December 29, 1982 Malcolm Smith finally killed himself in prison, after a series of attempts at suicide or self-mutilation. Richard Frankland, a commissioner for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody revisits friends and family to find out, not only the specific events, unique to Malcolm’s case, which led to his death, but also the more general issues which apply to all Aboriginals in custody, namely the application of penalties, which are out of all proportion to the crime and the removal of juveniles from their homes.
description_for_label: On December 29, 1982 Malcolm Smith finally killed himself in prison, after a series of attempts at suicide or self-mutilation. Richard Frankland, a commissioner for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody revisits friends and family to find out, not only the specific events, unique to Malcolm’s case, which led to his death, but also the more general issues which apply to all Aboriginals in custody, namely the application of penalties, which are out of all proportion to the crime and the removal of juveniles from their homes.

results.title: Mimi pulka
results.creator_credit: Catherine Adams, Ruth Carr, SBS-TV and Voice Productions
results.brief_description: In an effort to break down existing myths about HIV/AIDS and present the information in a way that was culturally appropriate for Aborigines, the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service in Broome commissioned a play entitled “No prejudice” and sent it on tour throughout the Kimberley region. This video follows the touring company of five actors and advisers and highlights the importance of why alternatives to the written word are necessary to a people whose culture is essentially oral.

results.title: The Kimberley mob
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Graeme Isaac, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Four International
results.brief_description: 1n 1967 Aborigines, were finally given equal rights and pay, but paradoxically this has meant that many Aboriginal stockmen are now considerably worse off. This film documents the struggles of the Watson brothers and their sons to reclaim the abandoned Mount Anderson Station in the Kimberleys for the Looma Community. Not only do they have to deal with threats to their land from mining companies, but they also struggle against the lack of support from their own community whose culture is under threat from the evangelical Assembly of God and alcohol.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Chase, Graeme Isaac, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Four International

results.title: Black man's houses
results.creator_credit: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: More than a hundred years after the Tasmanian Aborigines were declared extinct, their descendants set out to reclaim the lost graves of their ancestors on Flinders Island in Bass Strait. The neglected burial site at Wybalenna was, in the 1830’s, Australia’s first segregated Reserve, under the directorship of George Augustus Robinson and is now the battleground which divides a community. The film raises difficult questions about what constitutes Aboriginality today, and how colonial attitudes still linger on. Winner Best Australian Film at the Melbourne Film Festival.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Make It Right
results.creator_credit: Inst of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Central and Northern Land Councils
results.brief_description: An impressionistic account of the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke’s, 1988 visit to the Barunga Festival in remote Northern Territory. Thousands of Aboriginal people travel to this, the largest Aboriginal sports and cultural festival in Australia. In this particular year Mr. Hawke received a petition from the Aboriginal people for recognition of their rights, and in turn he pledged the drawing up of a treaty between black and white Australia. This treaty has yet to be made.

results.title: Aboriginal Education in Victoria: VAECG
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell, Open Channel Productions and Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre
results.brief_description: Explains the workings of the Victorian Aboriginal Education Consultative Group. Shows how the group operates with Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in Shepparton, Robinvale and Echuca. Introduced by Norman Lacy, Assistant Minister of Education.

results.title: Broken white line
results.brief_description: A documentation of the role of an Aboriginal social worker, depicting the enormity of the problems he is called upon to help solve in the Aboriginal community. DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE MATERIAL, TEACHER PREVIEW OF THE FILM BEFORE CLASSROOM SCREENING IS ESSENTIAL.

results.title: The Broken covenant
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Many of Australia’s urban Aborigines live in appalling physical conditions and are seen by some Australians as derelicts. But to Father Ted Kennedy, a Catholic priest who works in the inner-city suburb of Redfern, they still retain an essential quality of life missing in white society.

group_siblings.title: A Plain and sacred right
group_siblings.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC

results.title: Even chance
results.creator_credit: Martin Zierman, Sabina Baltrukomis, Victoria. Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity and Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed
results.brief_description: Alice, a young Aboriginal woman, leaves her home in a country town to work in the city. She finds employment but things start to go wrong and eventually she is dismissed. Alice decides to take her case to the Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity. The program highlights examples of harassment, prejudice, stereotyping and discrimination.
